bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, June 19, 1946

div1.p: Kean declines to write a chapter for Hench's book. He comments on the book's preparation.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, June 19, 1946
div1.opener:
Ac
K
Wednesday-
June 19/46 2804 N STREET, N. W.
WASHINGTON 7, D. C.
My dear Col. Hench
div1.p:
Mrs. Franck brought me yester-
day the carbon copies of the dictated
Qs and A's which she took on Wed. June 5-
She says she has been very busy at the office
of the Mil. Surg. and had to do the
work at home where she was much
interrupted (housekeeping etc)- She has
mailed you the first copy as you directed
and I went over the carbons last night
and will get them off today- I am
mailing this letter separately because
it relates to the future and not to the
past, and I feel that it should
have been sent a week ago-

It relates to the Foreword volume - about
which we talked when you were here-

I have never been a quick thinker, as you
and Gen. Ireland are, and my natural
deliberation has been much slowed, like
my physical movements, by age- You may
have observed when you discussed the
matter with me, that I was not enthu-
siastic- When I took up your little memo
of the contents and contributors and tried
to lay out in my mind how my chapter
should fit in with the others, which preced-
ed and followed it, it became clear to
me that a book cannot be written that
way; even with you as editor and largely
the author- It would be a medley, and
not an effective introduction to a great
story, It would not contribute to the sale
of the magnum opus, but rather would
determine the casual reader that if he had
paid $2.50 for it he would not invest
an additional $5.00 in the main work-
You have done a wonderful work in your
study of the Y. F. episode down to the petty
details, many of which will not appear in
your book but will be of value only if they
help your mind to see shades and details more
accurately- A man with newspaper training
like Burton J. Hendrick would never take this
trouble, and so he will never produce a great
work, tho he can write some like his
Virginia Lees (the 3 brothers of Stratford in
Revolutionary days) which are of interest and
value- You have the energy and ability
and the love of truth, with your wonderful
background of professional experience to satu-
rate your mind with the details and to
produce a great book- It will live for-
ever- I will not be alive to read it, but
I have had the joy of seeing its making,
and of contributing my mite to it- The
names of those men whose names are on your
3
Foreword memo, will mean nothing and
add nothing to this generation, which will
buy the book- They bore a parts in occur-
rences of nearly half a century ago. Do
not try to bring them forward when the
century half-hour strikes- It is not worth
the effort, as a matter of practical advan-
tage, and may be a detriment to your
great aim- Give what time you can spare
from your professional work to the big avoca-
tion of writing the book and dont let yourself
be lured off by side issues-

Cornelia has read this letter and agrees
with me and it is often that she does not
do so- She is far from being a Yes ma'am-
I wish inclose a memo about another matter
on a separate sheet- I hope you met Mrs
Hench at Harrisburg and were not too
much overloaded with stuff that you should
have sent home by express- Cordial regards to her
